title: Identification of Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence
chief_complaint: I feel unsteady and lose my balance when I turn my head quickly. My vision bounces when I walk or run, so I can't keep up with things visually. I also hear a loud heartbeat and fullness in my left ear.

problem_summary.course: Progressive worsening over time; symptoms increased significantly over a 3-year interval.
problem_summary.laterality: Bilateral vestibular symptoms; Left-sided auditory symptoms.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Oscillopsia, aural fullness (Left), pulsatile tinnitus (heartbeat sound), Tullio phenomenon (dizziness with loud sounds reported at follow-up).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Difficulty monitoring computer screens at work; eventually prevented driving and exercising.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Seeking explanation for unsteadiness and visual fixation issues after previous normal workups.

history.present_illness: 39-year-old female presenting with unsteadiness and oscillopsia (vision 'did not keep up') for 5 years. Reports difficulty walking on uneven surfaces. Reports aural fullness in the left ear and hearing a loud heartbeat.
history.otologic_history: Denied true vertigo, tinnitus (other than heartbeat), otalgia, or noise exposure.
history.prior_management: Previous normal audiological exam, EEG, CT, MRI, and MRA at an outside facility.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Normal air conduction thresholds bilaterally. Significant air-bone gaps in the Left ear (pseudo-conductive loss) and at 250 Hz in the Right ear. Left masked bone thresholds were at the audiometer limit (-10 dB HL).

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.key_findings: SRTs consistent with air thresholds. Excellent word recognition.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Present at normal levels ipsilaterally and contralaterally.

tests.name: Computerized Dynamic Posturography (CDP)
tests.key_findings: Composite score within normal limits. MCT and adaptation tests normal.

tests.name: VNG
tests.key_findings: All findings normal, including oculomotor, positioning, and caloric stimulation.

tests.name: cVEMP
tests.key_findings: Abnormally low threshold in the Left ear compared to the Right. Significant interaural threshold difference.

history.present_illness: Patient returned 3 years later. Reported increased oscillopsia preventing driving/exercise. Now experiencing Tullio phenomenon (dizziness with loud sounds) in the Left ear and increased aural fullness.
history.prior_management: Original CT scans were re-analyzed by a neuroradiologist, suggesting thinning of the superior canal, but resolution was inadequate for definitive diagnosis.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Mild low-frequency conductive hearing loss in the Left ear. Air-bone gaps increased compared to 3 years prior.

tests.name: CT Scan
tests.key_findings: Reconstructed CT revealed a clear dehiscence (loss of bone) overlying the superior semicircular canal on the left side.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.key_findings: Could not test (CNT) due to fluctuating compliance.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal air conduction thresholds but significant low-frequency air-bone gaps in the left ear, despite normal tympanometry and acoustic reflexes. Bone conduction thresholds are hypersensitive (better than 0 dB HL). cVEMP testing reveals a significantly lower threshold in the left ear compared to the right, consistent with a 'third window' pathology. Over a 3-year period, the air-bone gaps in the left ear widened, correlating with worsening vestibular symptoms and the emergence of Tullio phenomenon.
counseling_points: Your hearing test shows a 'false' conductive hearing loss; the inner ear is actually hypersensitive to bone-conducted sound due to a thinning of the bone covering the superior canal.
The symptoms you are experiencing—hearing your heartbeat, dizziness with loud sounds, and vision bouncing—are caused by a condition called Superior Semicircular Canal Dehiscence (SSCD).
The 'third window' created by the missing bone allows pressure to leak from the inner ear, which explains why you feel dizzy when you hear loud noises or strain.
Surgical repair is an option to plug or resurface the canal, which can help alleviate the dizziness and internal sounds.
notes_for_actor: Portray a patient who is frustrated by the 'invisibility' of the symptoms; you look fine, but your vision bounces when you walk.
Emphasize the internal sounds—hearing your own heartbeat is very distracting.
In the second visit, mention that loud noises now make you dizzy (Tullio phenomenon), which is a new and scary development.
You are an instructor, so you are articulate but distressed by your inability to focus on screens or drive.
